articles.headline: Obama Turns to Job Creation, but Warns of Limited Funds
articles.snippet: President Obama offered no promise that he could do much to ease joblessness quickly even as he comes under pressure from his own party to do more.
articles.abstract: President Obama offered no promise that he could do much to ease joblessness quickly even as he comes under pressure from his own party to do more.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON  After months of focusing on Afghanistan and health care, President Obama turned his attention on Thursday to the high level of joblessness, but offered no promise that he could do much to bring unemployment down quickly even as he comes under pressure from his own party to do more.

articles.headline: Why Many Home Loan Modifications Fail
articles.snippet: Many borrowers are failing to give banks proof of income or are unable to make the three monthly payments of the new lower amount required by the program.
articles.abstract: Many borrowers are failing to give banks proof of income or are unable to make the three monthly payments of the new lower amount required by the program.
articles.lead_paragraph: Why are so few temporary mortgage modifications turning permanent?

articles.headline: Abortion Battle Shifts to Clinic in Nebraska
articles.snippet: A Nebraska doctor has taken up the cause of late-term abortions from his slain colleague George R. Tiller.
articles.abstract: A Nebraska doctor has taken up the cause of late-term abortions from his slain colleague George R. Tiller.
articles.lead_paragraph: BELLEVUE, Neb.  The national battle over abortion, for decades firmly planted outside the Kansas clinic of Dr. George R. Tiller, has erupted here in suburban Omaha, where a longtime colleague has taken up the cause of late-term abortions.

articles.headline: C.I.A. to Expand Use of Drones in Pakistan
articles.snippet: The White House is expanding the program, paralleling the decision to send more troops to Afghanistan.
articles.abstract: The White House is expanding the program, paralleling the decision to send more troops to Afghanistan.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON  Two weeks ago in Pakistan, Central Intelligence Agency sharpshooters killed eight people suspected of being militants of the Taliban and Al Qaeda, and wounded two others in a compound that was said to be used for terrorist training.

articles.headline: Web-TV Divide Is Back in Focus With NBC Sale
articles.snippet: How people watch TV on demand will be a critical issue for Comcast, which is set to become a co-owner of Hulu.
articles.abstract: How people watch TV on demand will be a critical issue for Comcast, which is set to become a co-owner of Hulu.
articles.lead_paragraph: As she prepared her daughter for college, Anne Sweeney insisted that a television be among the dorm room accessories.

articles.headline: After Delays, Vaccine to Counter Bad Beef Is Being Tested
articles.snippet: A beef company has started a trial for a drug intended to reduce E. coli in cattle after years of bureaucratic delays in Washington.
articles.abstract: A beef company has started a trial for a drug intended to reduce E. coli in cattle after years of bureaucratic delays in Washington.
articles.lead_paragraph: HOLYOKE, Colo.  Jason Timmerman coaxed a balky calf into a chute on his feedlot one recent afternoon and jabbed a needle into its neck. He was injecting the animal with a new vaccine to make it immune to a dangerous form of the E. coli bacteria.

articles.headline: Citigroup Is Soon to Be the Last Wall St. Bank Held by U.S.
articles.snippet: Citigroup is the last of the Wall Street giants to remain tethered to government support, putting the struggling bank at a further disadvantage.
articles.abstract: Citigroup is the last of the Wall Street giants to remain tethered to government support, putting the struggling bank at a further disadvantage.
articles.lead_paragraph: Life just got harder for Vikram S. Pandit.
articles.byline: By Andrew Martin and Eric Dash

articles.headline: Potential Successor to Buffett Has Tough Task
articles.snippet: David L. Sokol, a possible heir apparent to Warren E. Buffett at Berkshire Hathaway, has his work cut out for him in addressing mounting problems at a luxury airline that is a part of Mr. Buffett’s holdings.
articles.abstract: David L. Sokol, a possible heir apparent to Warren E. Buffett at Berkshire Hathaway, has his work cut out for him in addressing mounting problems at a luxury airline that is a part of Mr. Buffett’s holdings.
articles.lead_paragraph: Maybe Warren E. Buffett should have stuck with railroads.

articles.headline: Jobs Report Is Strongest Since the Start of the Recession
articles.snippet: The sudden and unexpected improvement in job losses in November surprised even the most optimistic forecasters, as employers all but stopped shedding jobs.
articles.abstract: The sudden and unexpected improvement in job losses in November surprised even the most optimistic forecasters, as employers all but stopped shedding jobs.
articles.lead_paragraph: The nation’s employers not only have stopped eliminating large numbers of jobs, but appear to be on the verge of rebuilding the American work force, devastated by the recession.

articles.headline: Days After Chief’s Ouster, G.M. Shuffles Top Ranks
articles.snippet: Edward E. Whitacre Jr., G.M.’s new chief executive, assigned numerous executives to new roles.
articles.abstract: Edward E. Whitacre Jr., G.M.’s new chief executive, assigned numerous executives to new roles.
articles.lead_paragraph: DETROIT  Edward E. Whitacre Jr. wasted little time shaking up the management ranks of General Motors, just three days after he took over as chief executive, by promoting on Friday a cadre of young executives to carry out his mandate for change.

articles.headline: Report on Virginia Tech Shooting Finds Notification Delays
articles.snippet: At least two members of a group assembled to manage the crisis let their families know of the shootings over 90 minutes before warning the rest of the campus.
articles.abstract: At least two members of a group assembled to manage the crisis let their families know of the shootings over 90 minutes before warning the rest of the campus.
articles.lead_paragraph: RICHMOND, Va.  During the worst campus shooting spree in American history, Virginia Tech officials locked down some administrative offices and warned their own families more than an hour and a half before the rest of the campus was alerted, according to revisions made in the state’s official report on the rampage.
